string-array.name: sloth_facts
string-array.item: Captive sloths sleep about 15 to 18 hours a day.
A sloth\'s stomach can make up to two thirds of its body weight.
The three-toed sloth\'s scientific name, Bradypus, is Greek for \"slow feet.\"
The sloth is the world\'s slowest animal.
Sloths are so slow that algae grows on their fur.
A two-toed sloth can rotate its head nearly 90 degrees.
Sloths always look as if they\'re smiling due to the shape of their mouth.
Sloth claws are around 3 to 4 inches long.
Sloths poop once a week.
Ancient sloths grew to be as large as modern day elephants.
Ancient sloths roamed North America and became extinct around 10,000 years ago.
Sloths enjoy sleeping in the forks of trees.
Sloths live solo lives. The closest a sloth gets to socializing, aside from mating, is sleeping in the same tree with another sloth.
When a female sloth wants to mate, she will yell her \"mating scream\" to alert the males around her.
Males fight to mate by hanging from tree branches with their feet and pawing at each other with their front claws.
Sloths have a 4 part stomach, like cows.
It can take up to a month for a sloth to digest one meal.
Some species of sloths are threatened due to deforestation in Central and South America.
Two-toed sloths are mostly nocturnal, sleeping during the day.
There are 6 species of sloths, divided into 2 main families: two-toed sloths and three-toed sloths.
Sloths have difficulty walking on the ground due to their long claws.
Sloths sometimes eat the algae off of their own fur as a snack.
The algae that grows on sloths gives them a natural camouflage.
Sloths specialize in eating leaves, tender shoots, and buds.
Sloths can only manage to cover about 6–8 feet (1.8–2.4 meters) a minute.
Humans walk around 39 times faster than an average sloth\'s movement.
Sloths are surprisingly good swimmers.
When sloths swim, they use a lazy, doggy-paddle stroke to move through the water.
Sloths cannot shiver.
Baby sloths stay by their mother\'s side for up to 4 years.
The leaves of a sloth\'s diet are difficult to digest.
Sloths\' bodies are only 25% muscle.
If a sloth is too cold, it becomes unable to digest its food.
A sloth only has its claws for defense against predators.
Hibiscus flowers are considered \"sloth chocolate.\"
Sloths can retain their grip on tree branches after their death.
Wild sloths sleep for only around 9 and a half hours a day.
\"Perezoso\" is \"sloth\" in spanish.
An entire ecosystem can live on a single sloth.
A three-toed sloth can rotate its head up to 270 degrees in either direction.
The actress Kristen Bell is a big fan of sloths.
A single sloth may be home to moths, beetles, cockroaches, fungi, and algae.
There is a special kind of moth that has evolved to live in sloth fur.
Sloths\' primary predators are eagles, snakes, and jaguars.
Captive sloths can live up to 40 years.
Sloths are closely related to armadillos and anteaters.
Sloths are around 2–2.5 feet long.
Sloths weigh from 8 to 17 pounds, depending on the species.
In ancient times, there were several species of aquatic sloths, which are now extinct.
Two-toed sloths have been known to eat insects, small reptiles, and even birds.
Sloths can move up to 10 ft a minute in the trees.
Sloths can extend their tongues 10 to 12 inches out of their mouths.
Baby sloth cries sound like human babies.
When looking for mates, female sloths emit a bloodcurdling scream that can be heard for 700 meters.
Sloths move 3 times faster in water than on land.
The pygmy three-toed sloth is critically endangered, with only around 70 individuals remaining.
Wild sloths can live up to 20 years.
Sloths can hold their breath underwater for up to 40 minutes.
Sloths do not sweat.
Sloth fur grows away from the extremities due to their time spend hanging upside down.
Sloths can lose up to a third of their body weight by going to the bathroom.
The Cecropia leaves of a sloth\'s diet are highly toxic.
The orientation of their fur helps the rain water drip off their body.
Sloth stomachs house a mix of bacteria to help break down the tough leaves of their diet.
Sloths have the slowest digestion time of any mammal.
Sloths rely on the sun to regulate their body temperate.
Sloths maintain low body temperatures of 24 to 33 degrees.
Sloths are often sold as pets on the black market to tourists, with their claws removed.
Habitat loss has driven sloths into the city, where they become susceptible to being hit by cars, caught in electrical lines, or poached.
Sloth fur is very thick, coarse, and wiry.
When threatened, sloths can bite and produce high-pitched sounds to defend themselves.
Sloths have small molars that they use to chew up their leaves.
Sloths sometimes nest in the crowns of palm trees and camouflage as coconuts.
Female sloths give birth to one baby at a time.
Contrary to popular belief, sloths rarely die from a fall.
Sloths have half as much muscle tissue as other animals of similar weight.
Sloths have a very short and stubby tail.
Sloth fur aids in their ability to move swiftly through water.
In some areas, sloths have been estimated to comprise 70% of the biomass of arboreal mammals.
Three-toed sloths sleep during the night, contrary to their two-toed counterparts.
Sloths only move when necessary.
Sloths spend the bulk of their time feeding on a single tree\'s leaves.
Several zoos have accidentally purchased sloths of the wrong sex.
There is a sloth sanctuary in Costa Rica that cares for wounded and abandoned sloths.
Sloths spend most of their day sleeping and eating.
Sloths have been known to drop from trees straight into water to take a swim.
If a sloth feels threatened, they can go up to 4 meters a minute, however, this expends their energy quickly.
Sloths have only 10 upper teeth and 8 lower teeth.
When frightened, a sloth\'s fur \"puffs out,\" almost doubling its size.
An external coat of long coarse hair and dense smooth undercoat provides good insulation.
Sloths have 18 teeth.
Sloths have no enamel coating on their teeth.
Sloth teeth grows throughout its lifetime.
Sloths have small ears that are embedded in their fur close to their head.
Sloth are very hard of hearing.
Sloth\'s eyes are very mobile, and can be partly retracted into their skull when their eyelids are closed.
There is evidence that shows that sloths have adaptation to night vision.
Sloths often blink frequently and slowly, one eye at a time.
Sloths have difficulty maintaining their body temperature on rainy days.
Sloths give birth upside down.
Sloths have an excellent sense of smell.
Sloth infants separated from their mothers will let out a loud bleat lasting 30–90 seconds.
Sloths can hiss to defend themselves.
Sloths\' ears are particularly sensitive to low frequencies.
Sloth mouths house a large thick tongue, densely covered with sharp, backward-directed spines.
Sloths seldom drink, as moisture is obtained from plant matter and dew on the leaves they eat.
Sloth\'s milk is more nutritious than cow\'s milk.
Sloths pee and poop simultaneously.
Goat\'s milk is the only other milk that infant sloths can tolerate.
Sloth\'s milk contains many antibodies.
Sloths are born with their eyes open and claws fully formed.
Sloths are poached by hunters for their pelts, and sometimes their meat.
Sloths face habitat loss due to ranching, agriculture, urban expansion, and logging.
On average, sloths travel 41 yards per day; less than half the length of a football field.
Males are distinguishable from females as they usually have a bright yellow or orange patch located between their shoulders.
The giant ground sloth was likely hunted to extinction by man following the last Ice Age.
Sloths have a 120–150 day gestation period.
A sloth spends approximately 85% of its life hanging upside down.
All of its internal organs, including the heart, liver, spleen, and stomach, are arranged in such a way for a sloth to lead a life upside down.
Sloths take 6 seconds to have sex.
It takes a sloth 6 hours to go down its tree and go to the bathroom, and back up.
A baby sloth begins eating leaves at 2 months old.
Baby sloths are born fully furred.
Cold spells can be dangerous for sloth populations as they must move about to eat, but are not warm enough to move.
The sloth has the slowest metabolism of any mammal on Earth.
Both two-toed and three-toed sloths have three toes on their hind limbs.
Sloths become more inactive during the rainy season.
Orphaned baby sloths are given stuffed animals for them to hold onto.
Orphaned baby sloths are susceptible to illness as goat\'s milk lacks the antibodies of their mother\'s milk.
Sloths have no incisors or canines.
The only place sloths deposit fat is on the pads of their feet.
Sloths cannot fart.
Sloths have one baby at a time.
Twin sloths are incredibly rare, and when they do happen, the mother is unable to care for them both.
To move on ground, sloths dig into the earth with their front claws and pull themselves along, dragging their bellies across the forest floor.
The three-toed sloth emits a long, high-pitched call that echoes through the forests as "ahh-eeee."
